description:
## Overview

Make the Maestro app fully responsive across mobile, tablet, and desktop breakpoints with a primary breakpoint at `lg:` (1024px).

### Background & Strategic Rationale

This initiative transforms Maestro from a desktop-only application into a responsive, mobile-first experience. The goal is to maintain the rich desktop functionality while providing an excellent mobile/tablet experience.

**Why lg: (1024px) as the primary breakpoint?**
- Most tablets in landscape mode exceed 1024px, allowing them to use the "desktop" layout
- Phones and portrait tablets (typically <1024px) get the mobile-optimized layout
- This aligns with common industry practice and shadcn/ui defaults
- Simplifies decision-making: everything uses ONE breakpoint for responsive logic

**Current State Analysis:**
| Component | Current State | Mobile Ready? |
|-----------|---------------|---------------|
| Sidebar | Custom 306-line component, fixed 256px, no collapse | No |
| Issue View | Split panels with resize, tabs exist but use md: | Partial |
| Dashboard | 4-column kanban with horizontal scroll | No |
| Solo Pages | Full-width chat layouts | Mostly OK |
| Epic/Swarm Pages | Full-width with sections | Mostly OK |

---

### Wave 1: Parallel Prep (P0 tasks - can ALL run simultaneously)
```
ec5.1 ─┬─ Audit md: breakpoints
ec5.2 ─┼─ Audit other pages (solo/epic/swarm/ideate)  
ec5.3 ─┴─ Backup sidebar.tsx
```
**All 3 tasks are independent - assign to 3 parallel workers**

        ↓
ec5.15 → ec5.17                                  (Issue View - can run parallel to sidebar)
        ↓
ec5.10 ─┬─ Install accordion
ec5.11 ─┴─ Create compact cards (PARALLEL - no dependency on accordion!)
```

### Wave 3: Dashboard + Phase 4 (after their dependencies)

ec5.13 ─┴─ Accordion layout (needs ec5.10 + ec5.11)

ec5.20 ─┼─ Swarm page (needs ec5.2 + ec5.7)  
ec5.21 ─┴─ Ideate page (needs ec5.2 + ec5.7)
```
**Phase 4 tasks (18-21) can run in parallel with each other!**

### Wave 4: Final Testing
```
ec5.22 → ec5.23 ─┬─ 320px testing
         ec5.24 ─┴─ Touch targets (parallel)
                 ↓
         ec5.25    Final regression
```

### Optional (P3)
```
ec5.16    Toggle-group upgrade (after ec5.15, purely aesthetic)
```

---

## KEY INSIGHT: Maximum Parallelism

**With 3 workers, optimal assignment:**

| Time | Worker A | Worker B | Worker C |
|------|----------|----------|----------|
| T1 | ec5.1 (audit md:) | ec5.2 (audit pages) | ec5.3 (backup) |
| T2 | ec5.4 (install sidebar) | ec5.10 (install accordion) | ec5.15 (issue breakpoints) |
| T3 | ec5.5 (app-sidebar.tsx) | ec5.11 (compact cards) | ec5.17 (verify resize) |
| T4 | ec5.6 (layout.tsx) | ec5.12 (RecentChats) | ec5.18 (solo pages) |
| T5 | ec5.7 (SidebarTrigger) | ec5.13 (accordion layout) | ec5.19 (epic page) |
| T6 | ec5.8 (setOpenMobile) | ec5.14 (test transitions) | ec5.20 (swarm page) |
| T7 | ec5.9 (test sidebar) | ec5.21 (ideate page) | ec5.22 (cross-browser) |
| T8 | ec5.23 (320px) | ec5.24 (touch targets) | ec5.25 (final) |

---

## Acceptance Criteria

**Sidebar:**
- Uses shadcn Sidebar with `collapsible="offcanvas"` mode
- SidebarTrigger (hamburger) visible below lg: breakpoint
- Sidebar closes on navigation item click (mobile)
- Project tree structure preserved (expand/collapse)
- FolderBrowserModal accessible from sidebar
- Keyboard shortcut (cmd+b) works on desktop

**Dashboard:**
- Mobile (<1024px): Accordion by status + vertical chat list
- Desktop (>=1024px): Kanban + horizontal chat carousel
- "New Chat" action accessible in both layouts
- Issue counts shown in accordion headers

**Issue View:**
- Breakpoint aligned to lg: (1024px)
- Tab/toggle switching works on mobile
- Split view with resize on desktop
- Unread indicator works when on details tab

**General:**
- All views functional at 320px width minimum
- No unintentional horizontal scroll
- Touch-friendly tap targets (min 44px)
- Consistent lg: breakpoint usage across entire app
- SidebarTrigger visible in all page headers on mobile

---

**New Files to Create:**
- src/components/app-sidebar.tsx - Extracted sidebar content
- src/components/compact-cards.tsx - Mobile-optimized card variants
- src/components/ui/accordion.tsx - shadcn accordion

- Issue view breakpoint changes (minimal changes, 6 search-replace operations)
- Solo/Ideate page audits (likely minimal changes needed)

**Medium Risk:**
- Dashboard accordion implementation (new components, layout changes)
- Epic/Swarm page audits (may need layout adjustments for stats grid)

**Higher Risk:**
- Sidebar migration (largest change, replaces 306-line custom component)
- Potential for regression in project tree expand/collapse behavior
- FolderBrowserModal integration needs careful testing

---

## Testing Strategy

1. Test at multiple viewport widths: 320px, 375px, 768px, 1024px, 1440px
2. Test on actual devices (not just browser DevTools)
3. Verify keyboard shortcuts still work
4. Test navigation flows on mobile (sidebar close behavior)
5. Performance testing (no layout shifts, smooth transitions)

title: Phase 2.1: Install shadcn accordion component
description:
## Objective
Install the shadcn accordion component for use in the mobile dashboard layout.

## Background
On mobile, the 4-column kanban board doesn't fit. Instead, we'll use an accordion where each status (Issues, Ready, Active, Completed) is a collapsible section.

## Command
```bash
pnpm dlx shadcn@latest add accordion
```

## Expected Output
Creates `src/components/ui/accordion.tsx` with:
- Accordion (root)
- AccordionItem (each collapsible section)
- AccordionTrigger (the clickable header)
- AccordionContent (the collapsible body)

## Usage Pattern
```typescript
import { 
  Accordion, 
  AccordionItem, 
  AccordionTrigger, 
  AccordionContent 
} from "@/components/ui/accordion";

<Accordion type="single" collapsible defaultValue="issues">
  <AccordionItem value="issues">
    <AccordionTrigger>
      <CircleDot /> Issues <Badge>{count}</Badge>
    </AccordionTrigger>
    <AccordionContent>
      {/* Issue cards */}
    </AccordionContent>
  </AccordionItem>
  {/* More items... */}
</Accordion>
```

## Props to Know
- `type="single"` - Only one section open at a time
- `type="multiple"` - Multiple sections can be open
- `collapsible` - Allows closing all sections (with type="single")
- `defaultValue` - Which section is open by default

## For Dashboard
We'll use `type="single" collapsible defaultValue="issues"`:
- One section at a time (cleaner on mobile)
- Can close all if desired
- Issues section open by default

## Verification
After installation:
1. Check file exists: `src/components/ui/accordion.tsx`
2. No TypeScript errors
3. Can import from the component

## Files
- Creates: `src/components/ui/accordion.tsx`

Update all responsive breakpoints in the issue view from `md:` (768px) to `lg:` (1024px) for consistency with the rest of the app.

## Background
The issue view already has functioning mobile tabs and panel switching, but it uses `md:` breakpoint (768px). For consistency, we need to change to `lg:` (1024px).

+ <div className="hidden lg:flex flex-col w-[400px] border-r ...">
```

### Line 377: Mobile tabs container

+ <div className="flex border-t border-border lg:hidden">
```

### Lines 410-412: Details panel visibility
```diff

-   className={`${activeTab === "details" ? "flex" : "hidden"} md:flex flex-col w-full ...`}
+   className={`${activeTab === "details" ? "flex" : "hidden"} lg:flex flex-col w-full ...`}
```

### Line 413: Panel width conditional

-   style={{ width: typeof window !== "undefined" && window.innerWidth >= 768 ? panelWidth : undefined }}

+   className={`${activeTab === "chat" ? "flex" : "hidden"} lg:flex flex-col ...`}

You can use these patterns:
- `md:hidden` → `lg:hidden` (2 occurrences)
- `md:flex` → `lg:flex` (3 occurrences)
- `md:block` → `lg:block` (1 occurrence)

## Objective
Verify that the panel resize handle is hidden on mobile and that panel width behavior works correctly.

## Current Implementation
The resize handle (line 417-419):
```typescript
<div 
  className={cn(
    "absolute right-0 top-0 bottom-0 w-1 cursor-col-resize transition-colors z-10 hidden md:block",
    isDragging ? "bg-primary" : "hover:bg-primary/30"
  )}
  onMouseDown={handleMouseDown}
/>
```

## Changes Needed
After Phase 3.1, this will be `lg:block` instead of `md:block`.

## Testing Checklist

### Mobile (< 1024px)
- [ ] Resize handle is NOT visible
- [ ] Cannot drag to resize panels
- [ ] Tab switching controls which panel is visible
- [ ] Panels take full width when active

### Desktop (>= 1024px)
- [ ] Resize handle IS visible on hover (subtle line)
- [ ] Cursor changes to `col-resize` when hovering handle
- [ ] Dragging handle resizes left panel
- [ ] Minimum width enforced (200px per code)
- [ ] Maximum width enforced (50% of viewport per code)
- [ ] Width persists in localStorage (`issue-panel-width`)
- [ ] Width restored on page reload

### Edge Cases
- [ ] Resize to exactly 1024px - handle should appear
- [ ] Resize to 1023px - handle should disappear
- [ ] Start dragging, then resize window to mobile - should handle gracefully
- [ ] Very narrow desktop (1024px) - resize should still work within limits

## Code Review Points

### Width Calculation (line 413)
```typescript
style={{ width: typeof window !== "undefined" && window.innerWidth >= 1024 ? panelWidth : undefined }}
```
This ensures:
- On mobile: no inline width style (panel uses flex/full width)
- On desktop: uses panelWidth from state

### Drag Constraints (line 210)
```typescript
const newWidth = Math.max(200, Math.min(e.clientX, window.innerWidth * 0.5))
```
This ensures:
- Minimum 200px width
- Maximum 50% of viewport
- Responsive to current viewport size

## Potential Issues to Watch
1. **SSR hydration**: `typeof window !== "undefined"` check is critical
2. **Stale state**: If window resizes while dragging, constraints use current size
3. **Touch devices**: Mouse events only - touch resize not implemented (acceptable)

## Objective
Ensure the mobile sidebar closes automatically when users click any navigation link within it.

## Background
On mobile, when users tap a link in the sidebar (e.g., a project, an issue, or "Solo Chat"), the sidebar should close so they can see the page they navigated to. Without this, the sidebar remains open and covers the content.

## Implementation

### Option 1: Wrapper Component (Recommended)
Create a reusable NavLink component inside app-sidebar.tsx:

```typescript
function SidebarNavLink({ href, children, className, ...props }) {
  const { setOpenMobile } = useSidebar();
  
  return (
    <Link 
      href={href} 
      onClick={() => setOpenMobile(false)}
      className={className}
      {...props}
    >
      {children}
    </Link>
  );
}
```

Use this for all navigation links in the sidebar.

### Option 2: Direct onClick Handlers
Add onClick handlers directly to each Link:

```typescript
const { setOpenMobile } = useSidebar();

<Link 
  href={`/project/${project.id}`}
  onClick={() => setOpenMobile(false)}
>
  {project.displayName}
</Link>
```

1. **Project names** - clicking navigates to project dashboard
2. **Issue links** - clicking navigates to issue view
3. **"New Idea" button** - navigates to ideate page
4. **"Solo Chat" button** - navigates to solo page

### Non-Navigation Clicks

- Expand/collapse project tree (toggleProjectExpanded)
- Opening FolderBrowserModal (add project button)

description:
## Overview

Implement the Issue Discussion view - a split-panel interface where users explore and refine GitHub Issues with an AI agent, using the GitHub issue itself as the persistent source of truth.

## Architectural Philosophy

This feature embodies a key architectural principle: **GitHub Issues ARE the persistent artifact**. Unlike traditional chat applications where conversation history is stored separately, we use GitHub Issues as the canonical source of truth. OpenCode sessions are transient - they can be recreated at any time by re-injecting the issue context.

### Key Design Decisions

1. **No git branch/worktree during discussion** - Agent operates on main branch in read-only exploration mode
2. **GitHub Issue IS persistence** - Not local files, not OpenCode session state
3. **Sessions are ephemeral** - Can be recreated by injecting issue context
4. **Summary persistence is on-demand** - User explicitly saves conversation summaries as GitHub comments
5. **No new concepts** - We work directly with GitHub Issues

## Why This Matters

The Issue Discussion phase is the first step in the Maestro workflow:

```
Issue Discussion → Planning → Execution (Swarm/Solo) → Completion
```

Users need a space to:
- Explore ideas with AI assistance
- Understand codebase implications
- Refine requirements before committing to implementation
- Build shared context that persists beyond any single conversation

## Technical Context

### Already Implemented
- NewIssueDialog component (creates GitHub issues)
- Issue View page (basic split panel, but chat is mocked)
- Issues API endpoints (list, create, get single)
- Mobile tabbed interface
- Desktop split panel (fixed 400px width)

### Needs Implementation
- OpenCode SDK integration (replacing mock setTimeout)
- Session storage service (~/.maestro/sessions.json)
- Comments display in issue panel
- Add comment API endpoint
- Session management API endpoints
- SSE streaming for real-time responses
- Save Summary modal
- Error handling infrastructure
- Panel resizing (polish)

## Parallelization Opportunities

**Can be worked in parallel:**
- Task 1.1 (Install SDK) + Task 1.3 (SessionStorage) - no dependencies between them
- Task 3.1 (Display comments) - pure UI, no dependencies at all
- Task 3.2 (Comment posting API) - independent of OpenCode work
- Task 4.2 (Panel resizing) - independent UI polish

**Critical path:**
1.1 → 1.2 → 1.4 → 2.1 → 2.3 → 2.4

**Merge notes:**
- Task 2.2 was merged into 1.4 (context injection is part of session creation)

## OpenCode SDK Key Points

**Critical: Directory Parameter**
The OpenCode SDK operates on a specific project directory. Almost every API call requires a `directory` query parameter. Our services must pass the project path to OpenCode.

**Streaming Pattern**
For real-time streaming, use:
1. `session.promptAsync()` - starts prompt, returns immediately
2. `event.subscribe()` - SSE stream for updates
3. Listen for `message.part.updated` events with `delta` property

**Health Check**
Use `client.global.health()` for connectivity checks.

## Dependencies

External:
- OpenCode server running locally (`opencode serve`)
- @opencode-ai/sdk npm package
- GitHub CLI (`gh`) authenticated

Internal:
- ConfigService (for project paths) - EXISTS
- TanStack Query hooks pattern - EXISTS
- UI component library - EXISTS

## Success Criteria

1. User can chat with AI about a GitHub issue
2. AI has full issue context (title, body, comments)
3. AI can read codebase but cannot modify files
4. Conversation summaries can be saved to GitHub
5. Sessions reconnect gracefully if interrupted
6. Works on both desktop and mobile layouts

## Reference

GitHub Issue: https://github.com/ejohane/maestro/issues/3
OpenCode SDK Docs: https://opencode.ai/docs/sdk

title: Create session management API endpoints
description:
## Task

Create API endpoints for managing OpenCode sessions tied to GitHub issues:
- `POST /api/projects/[id]/issues/[issueNumber]/session` - Create/resume session
- `GET /api/projects/[id]/issues/[issueNumber]/session` - Get existing session ID

**This task also includes context injection** - when a session is created, the full GitHub issue context is injected.

## Why

The frontend needs a way to:
1. Get or create a session when opening an issue
2. Know which session ID to use for chat

## Implementation

### GET /api/projects/[id]/issues/[issueNumber]/session

Returns existing session ID if alive, or null.

```typescript
// Response (200)
{ sessionId: string | null }

// Response (404)
{ error: "Issue not found" }
```

**Logic:**
1. Get project from config (need project.path for OpenCode)
2. Check sessionStorage for existing mapping
3. If mapping exists, verify session is alive via OpenCodeService.isSessionAlive(projectPath, sessionId)
4. If alive, touch session timestamp, return sessionId
5. If dead, remove mapping, return null

### POST /api/projects/[id]/issues/[issueNumber]/session

Creates new session with context injection.

```typescript
// Response (201)
{ sessionId: string }

// Response (500)
{ error: "Failed to create session" }
```

**Logic:**
1. Get project from config (need project.path)
2. Fetch issue details (title, body, comments) via gh CLI
3. Create new OpenCode session via openCodeService.createSession(projectPath, title)
4. Inject issue context via openCodeService.injectContext(projectPath, sessionId, context)
5. Save session mapping to sessionStorage (with projectPath)
6. Return sessionId

## Context Injection Format

```typescript
function buildIssueContext(issue: GitHubIssue): string {
  const comments = issue.comments?.length
    ? issue.comments.map(c =>
        `**@${c.author.login}** (${new Date(c.createdAt).toLocaleDateString()}):\n${c.body}`
      ).join("\n\n")
    : "No comments yet."

  return `## GitHub Issue #${issue.number}

**Title:** ${issue.title}
**State:** ${issue.state}
**Author:** @${issue.author.login}
**Labels:** ${issue.labels.map(l => l.name).join(", ") || "None"}
**Created:** ${new Date(issue.createdAt).toLocaleDateString()}

### Description
${issue.body || "No description provided."}

### Comments
${comments}

---
You are helping discuss this GitHub issue. You can read the codebase to answer questions and suggest approaches, but you cannot modify any files. Focus on exploration and understanding.`
}
```

## Key Design Points

1. **Pass projectPath to OpenCode** - Required for OpenCode to know which project
2. **Context uses synthetic: true** - On the text part, not the body
3. **Context uses noReply: true** - Do not generate AI response for injection
4. **Store projectPath in sessionStorage** - For future verification

## Files to Create

- `src/app/api/projects/[id]/issues/[issueNumber]/session/route.ts`

- SessionStorageService (task 1.3)

- [ ] GET returns null if no session
- [ ] GET removes stale mappings for dead sessions
- [ ] POST creates new session with correct projectPath
- [ ] POST injects full issue context with synthetic: true, noReply: true
- [ ] POST saves mapping to sessionStorage with projectPath
- [ ] Proper error handling for missing project/issue

title: Implement context injection on session start
description:
## Task

When a new session is created, inject the full GitHub issue context so the AI understands what is being discussed.

## Why

Without context injection, the AI would have no idea what issue the user is discussing. By injecting title, body, comments, and instructions upfront, every message benefits from this context.

## How Context Injection Works

OpenCode SDK supports `synthetic: true` messages that appear in the context but were not typed by the user:

```typescript
await client.session.prompt({
  path: { id: sessionId },
  body: {
    noReply: true,      // Do not generate AI response
    parts: [{
      type: "text",
      text: buildIssueContext(issue),
      synthetic: true   // Mark as system-injected, not user message
    }]
  }
})
```

description:
## Phase 4: Polish & Error Handling

This phase adds robustness, better UX, and handles edge cases that make the difference between a prototype and a production-quality feature.

### Why This Phase Last?

Core functionality must work first (Phases 1-3). Polish is important but not blocking. Users can use a working feature with rough edges; they can't use a polished feature that doesn't work.

### Error Handling Strategy

**Hierarchy of Errors**
```
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ [Global Banner - server connectivity]       │  ← Persistent until resolved
├─────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│   Issue Details        │  Chat Area         │
│   [Inline error if     │  [Inline error if  │  ← Contextual errors
│    issue fetch fails]  │   session fails]   │
│                        │  [Toast for        │  ← Transient notifications
│                        │   minor issues]    │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

**Specific Error Scenarios**
| Scenario | UI Behavior |
|----------|-------------|
| OpenCode unreachable | Banner: "Cannot connect to OpenCode server" + Retry |
| GitHub API failure | Inline error + Retry button |
| Rate limit | Banner with reset time |
| Session dies | Auto-recreate with "Reconnecting..." toast |
| Message send fails | Keep message in input, show error, enable retry |
| Issue not found | 404 page with link back |

### UX Polish

**Panel Resizing**
Currently hardcoded at 400px. Should be draggable with:
- Mouse drag handle
- Min/max constraints (200px - 50% of viewport)
- Persist preference to localStorage

**Mobile Unread Indicator**

- Show badge on Chat tab
- Clear badge when user switches to Chat tab

**Loading States**
- Skeleton loader for issue details
- "Starting conversation..." spinner
- Typing indicator (pulsing dots)
- Streaming text (progressive reveal)
- "Creating..." states for buttons

**Empty States**
- No description: italic "No description provided."
- No comments: section hidden or subtle message

## Task Add inline error handling for specific failure scenarios that do not warrant a global banner. ## Why Not all errors are equal: - OpenCode server down = global banner (affects all features) - Single API call failed = contextual inline error - Network hiccup = toast with retry Matching error severity to UI treatment reduces alarm fatigue. ## Error Scenarios ### Issue Fetch Failed Show inline error in Issue Details panel: ```tsx {issueError && (

title: Project List: Add and Manage Projects via Remote Filesystem Browser
description:
## Overview

Implement the project list view - the main entry point to Maestro. This replaces the current mock data with a real persistence layer and adds a custom folder browser for adding projects from the server's filesystem.

## Background & Context

### Why This Matters
Maestro is a mobile-friendly web frontend for OpenCode that runs on a user's dev machine and is accessed remotely via Tailscale. The project list is the **first screen users see** and the **foundation for all other features**. Without real project persistence, nothing else in Maestro can function.

### Technical Constraint: Remote Access
Because Maestro runs as a Next.js server on the dev machine but is accessed from remote clients (phone, tablet, another laptop via Tailscale):
- **Browser file picker APIs won't work** - they open on the client device, not the server
- **We need a custom server-side folder browser** that exposes the server's filesystem
- **All storage is server-side** - config lives at `~/.maestro/config.json` on the dev machine

### Current State
- `src/app/page.tsx` displays mock projects from `src/lib/data/mock.ts`
- `src/components/ui/sidebar.tsx` also uses mock data
- No API routes exist yet
- No persistence layer exists

### Target State
- Real project storage in `~/.maestro/config.json`
- Full CRUD API for projects
- Filesystem browsing API (constrained to home directory)
- Folder browser modal for adding projects
- Project card management (edit name, remove, relocate missing)
- Proper loading/error states throughout

## Task Structure (10 Tasks)

### Foundation Layer (P0) - Sequential start
1. **Foundation: Dependencies & React Query Setup** - Install dependencies, add shadcn components, set up QueryClientProvider
2. **Config Service** - Create `~/.maestro/config.json` persistence layer with type-safe CRUD operations

### API Layer (P0) - Can parallelize after Config Service
3. **Projects API** - All 4 endpoints: GET, POST, PATCH, DELETE /api/projects
4. **Filesystem Browse API** - GET /api/filesystem/browse endpoint for folder picker

### Data Layer (P1) - Bridges backend to frontend
5. **React Query Hooks** - useProjects, useAddProject, useUpdateProject, useDeleteProject, useFilesystem

### UI Layer (P1) - Core user-facing features
6. **FolderBrowserModal** - Complete modal with directory list, breadcrumbs, and add project form
7. **Project List Page** - Replace mock data, add loading/error/empty states, header Add button

### Polish Layer (P2) - Enhanced UX (can parallelize 28 & 31)
8. **ProjectCard Component** - Extract card with dropdown menu, edit name dialog
9. **Missing Project Detection & Relocate** - Warning UI for missing projects, relocate dialog
10. **Sidebar Integration** - Fetch from API, wire + button to folder browser

## Dependency Graph (Corrected)
```
[22. Foundation] 
      |
      v
[23. Config Service]
      |
      +---------------+
      |               |
      v               v
[24. Projects API] [25. Filesystem API]
      |               |
      +-------+-------+
              |
              v
      [26. React Query Hooks]
              |
              v
      [27. FolderBrowserModal]
              |
      +-------+-------+
      |               |
      v               v
[28. Project List] [31. Sidebar]
      |
      v
[29. ProjectCard]
      |
      v
[30. Missing/Relocate]
```

## Parallelization Opportunities
- **Wave 3**: Tasks 24 and 25 can run in parallel (both depend only on 23)
- **Wave 6**: Tasks 28 and 31 can run in parallel (both depend on 26 and 27)

## Key Design Decisions

### UUID-based Project IDs
Projects get UUID v4 identifiers used in routing (`/project/[id]`). This decouples the URL from the filesystem path, allowing projects to be relocated without breaking links.

### Display Name Derivation
When no custom name is set, derive from path: `/Users/erik/dev/my-project` -> `my-project`.

### Security Boundary
All filesystem operations constrained to user's home directory. No browsing `/etc`, `/usr`, etc.

### FolderBrowserModal Reuse
The modal supports both "Add Project" and "Relocate Project" modes via props, avoiding code duplication.

### Symlink Resolution
Paths are resolved via `fs.realpath()` before storing to avoid issues when symlinks change.

## References

- AGENTS.md: Development workflow guidelines

title: 1. Foundation: Dependencies & React Query Setup
description:
## Purpose
Set up the foundational dependencies and infrastructure needed by all other tasks. This is the first task to complete.

## Dependencies to Install
```bash
bun add @tanstack/react-query
```

## shadcn Components to Add
```bash
npx shadcn@latest add dialog dropdown-menu input label scroll-area alert
```

These components are used by:
- **Dialog**: FolderBrowserModal, EditNameDialog, RelocateDialog
- **DropdownMenu**: ProjectCard menu
- **Input**: Name input in dialogs, path input in folder browser
- **Label**: Form labels in dialogs
- **ScrollArea**: Mobile-friendly scrollable directory list in folder browser
- **Alert**: Error state displays

## React Query Provider Setup

### Create providers.tsx
```typescript
// src/app/providers.tsx
"use client";
import { QueryClient, QueryClientProvider } from "@tanstack/react-query";
import { useState } from "react";

export function Providers({ children }: { children: React.ReactNode }) {
  const [queryClient] = useState(() => new QueryClient({
    defaultOptions: {
      queries: {
        staleTime: 5 * 60 * 1000, // 5 minutes - projects change rarely
        retry: 1,
        refetchOnWindowFocus: true, // Refetch when user switches back from file operations
      },
    },
  }));
  
  return (
    <QueryClientProvider client={queryClient}>
      {children}
    </QueryClientProvider>
  );
}
```

### Update layout.tsx
Wrap the app with Providers in the root layout:
```typescript
import { Providers } from "./providers";

export default function RootLayout({ children }) {
  return (
    <html>
      <body>
        <Providers>{children}</Providers>
      </body>
    </html>
  );
}
```

## Why These Choices
- **React Query**: Automatic caching, background refetching, optimistic updates, request deduplication
- **useState for QueryClient**: Required for App Router to avoid recreating on each render
- **staleTime 5 minutes**: Projects change rarely; no need for frequent refetching
- **refetchOnWindowFocus**: Ensures fresh data when user returns from filesystem operations
- **retry 1**: Fail fast if server is down

title: 3. Projects API: GET, POST, PATCH, DELETE endpoints
description:
## Purpose
Implement all four CRUD endpoints for projects. These are the backbone of the project management feature.

## Endpoints Overview

| Method | Path | Purpose |
|--------|------|---------|
| GET | /api/projects | List all projects with computed fields |
| POST | /api/projects | Add a new project |
| PATCH | /api/projects/[id] | Update name or relocate path |
| DELETE | /api/projects/[id] | Remove project from tracking |

---

## GET /api/projects

Returns all projects with computed fields and validation status.

### Response Schema
```typescript
interface ProjectsResponse {
  projects: Project[];
}

interface Project {
  id: string;
  path: string;              // Absolute: /Users/erik/dev/project
  displayPath: string;       // Friendly: ~/dev/project
  name: string | null;       // Custom name or null
  displayName: string;       // name ?? derived from path
  addedAt: string;           // ISO 8601
  status: "active" | "missing";
}
```

### Implementation
- Fetch all projects from config service
- For each project, check if path exists (`fs.access`)
- Compute displayPath, displayName, status
- Sort by addedAt descending (most recent first)
- Return empty array when no projects (not error)

---

## POST /api/projects

Add a new project.

### Request
```json
{
  "path": "/Users/erik/dev/my-project",
  "name": "My Project"
}
```

`name` is optional (omit or set to null to derive from path).

### Validation (in order)
1. `path` required and non-empty string
2. Path must be within home directory (security) -> 403
3. Resolve symlinks with `fs.realpath()`
4. Path must exist -> 404
5. Path must be a directory -> 400
6. Path must not already be tracked -> 409

### Response
- 201 with created project object on success
- Error responses with `{ error: "message" }`

---

## PATCH /api/projects/[id]

Update name or relocate path.

### Request
```json
{
  "name": "New Name",
  "path": "/new/path"
}
```

At least one field required. Both optional.

### Validation
- Project must exist -> 404
- If path provided: same validation as POST (exists, is directory, in home, not duplicate)
- If path is same as current: no-op (not an error, just return current state)
- Empty name or whitespace-only -> treat as null (use derived)

### Response
- 200 with updated project object
- Error responses with `{ error: "message" }`

---

## DELETE /api/projects/[id]

Remove project from tracking (not from disk).

### Response
- 204 No Content on success
- 204 even if project doesn't exist (idempotent)

---

## Shared Response Type
```typescript
// Used in GET list item, POST response, PATCH response
interface Project {
  id: string;
  path: string;
  displayPath: string;
  name: string | null;
  displayName: string;
  addedAt: string;
  status: "active" | "missing";
}
```

## Error Response Format
All errors return:
```json
{
  "error": "Human-readable error message"

title: 4. Filesystem Browse API endpoint
description:
## Purpose
Implement the `GET /api/filesystem/browse` endpoint for the folder picker UI. This enables users to navigate the server's filesystem to select project directories.

## Why Custom Browsing?
Maestro runs on the dev machine but is accessed remotely (via Tailscale). Browser file picker APIs open on the **client** device, not the server. We need a custom API that exposes the server's filesystem in a controlled way.

## Security Constraints
**Critical**: This endpoint exposes the filesystem. Security measures:
1. **Home directory only** - Cannot browse outside `~`
2. **Directories only** - Don't list files
3. **Hidden directories filtered** - No `.git`, `.config`, `.ssh`, etc.
4. **Permission errors handled gracefully** - Skip unreadable dirs

## Query Parameters
| Param | Required | Default | Description |
|-------|----------|---------|-------------|
| `path` | No | `~/dev` or `~` | Directory to list |

If `path` not provided:
- Try `~/dev` first (common convention)
- Fall back to `~` if `~/dev` doesn't exist

## Response Schema
```typescript
interface BrowseResponse {
  currentPath: string;    // Absolute: /Users/erik/dev
  displayPath: string;    // Friendly: ~/dev
  parent: string | null;  // Parent path, null if at home
  canGoUp: boolean;       // false if at home directory
  directories: Directory[];
}

interface Directory {
  name: string;           // Directory name
  path: string;           // Absolute path
  isGitRepo: boolean;     // Has .git subdirectory
}
```

## Implementation
```typescript
// src/app/api/filesystem/browse/route.ts
const HIDDEN_PATTERNS = [
  /^\./,                 // Hidden dirs (., .git, .config, etc)
  /^node_modules$/,
  /^__pycache__$/,
  /^\.cache$/,
  /^vendor$/,
  /^\.?venv$/,
  /^.next$/,            // Next.js build output
  /^dist$/,             // Common build output
  /^build$/,            // Common build output
  /^target$/,           // Rust/Maven build output
  /^coverage$/,         // Test coverage
  /^\.nyc_output$/,    // NYC coverage
];

function shouldHide(name: string): boolean {
  return HIDDEN_PATTERNS.some(pattern => pattern.test(name));
}

// Add timeout wrapper for filesystem operations
async function withTimeout<T>(promise: Promise<T>, ms: number): Promise<T> {
  const timeout = new Promise<never>((_, reject) =>
    setTimeout(() => reject(new Error('Filesystem timeout')), ms)
  );
  return Promise.race([promise, timeout]);
}

export async function GET(request: Request) {
  // 1. Determine path (from query or default)
  // 2. Security check: must be within home
  // 3. Validate path exists and is directory (with 5s timeout)
  // 4. Read directory entries (with 5s timeout)
  // 5. Filter to visible directories
  // 6. Check each for .git subdirectory
  // 7. Sort alphabetically (case-insensitive)
  // 8. Compute parent/canGoUp using configService.getParentPath()
  // 9. Return response
}
```

## Git Repo Detection
Check for `.git` subdirectory to identify git repos. This helps users visually distinguish project directories from regular folders.

## Error Responses
| Status | Condition |
|--------|-----------|
| 400 | Invalid path parameter |
| 403 | Path outside home directory |
| 404 | Path does not exist |
| 500 | Filesystem timeout (network drive issues) |

## Edge Cases
- **Permission denied on subdirectory**: Skip it, don't fail request
- **Symlink directory**: Follow it, check resolved path is within home
- **Race condition (dir deleted while reading)**: Skip missing entries
- **Network drive timeout**: Fail after 5 seconds with clear error

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Returns directories at requested path
- [ ] Defaults to ~/dev (or ~ if no ~/dev)
- [ ] Hides hidden directories (starting with .)
- [ ] Hides node_modules, __pycache__, vendor, venv
- [ ] Hides build output directories (.next, dist, build, target, coverage)
- [ ] Shows isGitRepo indicator for git repos
- [ ] Provides parent path for navigation (using configService.getParentPath())
- [ ] Returns canGoUp: false at home directory
- [ ] Returns 403 for paths outside home
- [ ] Returns 404 for non-existent paths
- [ ] Handles permission errors gracefully (skips unreadable)
- [ ] Directories sorted alphabetically (case-insensitive)
- [ ] 5 second timeout for filesystem operations

title: Integrate AI Elements into Chat Interface
description:
## Overview

Integrate Vercel's AI Elements component library into Maestro's chat interface to provide a polished, modern AI chat experience with proper message rendering, markdown support, code blocks, and rich input controls.

## Background

AI Elements (https://ai-sdk.dev/elements) is a component library built on shadcn/ui that provides pre-built, customizable React components specifically designed for AI applications. Key features:
- Professional message rendering with markdown support
- Syntax-highlighted code blocks
- Collapsible reasoning/thinking displays
- Source citations
- Rich prompt input with model selection and attachments
- Copy/regenerate message actions

## Current State

The Issue Discussion page (`src/app/project/[id]/issue/[issueNumber]/page.tsx`) has:
- Custom chat implementation with manual SSE streaming
- Basic message bubbles (user/assistant distinction)
- Works with OpenCode SDK backend via custom API routes
- Session management with auto-reconnection
- ~773 lines of code mixing UI and logic

## Integration Strategy

Since AI Elements components are installed as source code (not library imports), we can adapt them to work with our existing OpenCode backend rather than requiring Vercel AI SDK's `useChat` hook.

**Approach:**
1. Install AI Elements components into the project
2. Create adapter layer that bridges OpenCode SDK streaming to component props
3. Progressively replace custom message rendering with AI Elements components
4. Enhance input experience with PromptInput component
5. Add markdown rendering and code block support to messages

## Key Technical Considerations

1. **Backend Compatibility**: Keep existing OpenCode SDK integration, adapt frontend only
2. **Streaming Format**: Current SSE `data: {"delta": "..."}` format needs to feed into component state
3. **Message Parts**: AI Elements uses `parts` array for messages (text, reasoning, sources), adapt our flat `content` string
4. **Styling**: AI Elements uses Tailwind CSS 4 and CSS variables - verify compatibility

## Dependencies

- AI Elements CLI (`npx ai-elements@latest`)
- shadcn/ui already installed in project
- React 19 (already using)
- Tailwind CSS 4 (already using)

## Out of Scope

- Changing the OpenCode backend integration
- Adding new AI features (reasoning, sources) - just UI preparation
- Modifying the session/chat API routes
